result_equations.equation: f' = f (1 +- v/v_wave) (moving source, stationary observer)

explanation: The Classical Doppler effect describes the change in frequency of waves when there is relative motion between the source and observer. When the source and observer approach each other, the frequency increases; when they recede, it decreases. This effect applies to sound waves, water waves, and other classical waves, differing from the relativistic Doppler effect for light.

equations_assumptions.text: The wave speed is constant in the medium and much larger than source/observer speeds.
Motion is along the line connecting source and observer.

definitions.definition: Original frequency emitted by the source.
Speed of waves in the medium.
Speed of observer (positive when moving toward source).
Speed of source (positive when moving toward observer).
Relative velocity between source and observer.

derivation.equation: General case: f' = f (v_wave +- v_observer)/(v_wave +- v_source)

derivation_assumptions.text: The medium is stationary relative to the chosen reference frame.
Wave propagation is linear and the medium is non-dispersive.

derivation_explanation.text: Start with the basic wave relation between wavelength, frequency, and wave speed.
Consider first the case where only the observer is moving.
The relative speed between waves and observer changes the effective wave speed.
The observed frequency is the relative speed divided by wavelength.
Substitute to get the frequency shift for moving observer.
Now consider the case where only the source is moving.
A moving source changes the effective wavelength of the emitted waves.
The observed frequency uses the modified wavelength but unchanged wave speed.
Combine both effects for the general case with both source and observer moving.

limitations: Does not apply to electromagnetic waves in vacuum
